A database schema is the blueprint or structure that describes the logical organization of data in a database. It defines how data is organized, what relationships exist between data elements, and the constraints that apply to the data.

A database schema is typically represented visually as a diagram called an entity-relationship diagram (ERD). The ERD is a graphical representation of the schema that shows the tables or entities, their attributes or columns, and the relationships between them.

Here's an example of an ERD for a simple database schema:

In this example, we have three tables or entities: customers, orders, and order\_items. The tables are represented by rectangles with the table name at the top. The attributes or columns of each table are listed below the table name. The primary key for each table is underlined, and foreign keys are shown as arrows pointing to the referenced table.

The relationships between the tables are shown by the lines connecting the tables. In this example, we have a one-to-many relationship between customers and orders (i.e., one customer can have many orders), and a one-to-many relationship between orders and order\_items (i.e., one order can have many order items).

Overall, the ERD provides a clear and concise way to understand the structure of a database schema, making it easier to design, implement, and maintain the database.
